rows.FUTURE PRESS RELEASE: Amazon's 'Working Backwards' technique: Write the success story first
THE TECHNIQUE
Write a press release as if it's 18 months from now and you've succeeded.
This forces clarity on: What does success look like? What's the story?
Work backwards from this to figure out what needs to be true.
Date this press release 18 months from today: [INSERT DATE]
THE NEW YORK TIMES
Business Section | [DATE + 18 MONTHS]
IonWave Disrupts $5B Electrolyte Market With Ocean-Sourced Formula, Hits $1.2M Annual Revenue
By [Reporter Name], Health & Wellness Correspondent
In an industry dominated by synthetic formulas and sugar-laden sports drinks, a small startup has carved out a devoted following by going back to basics—or more precisely, back to the ocean.

IonWave, founded just 18 months ago, has reached $100,000 in monthly recurring revenue by selling a premium electrolyte powder containing 78 trace minerals sourced from pristine ocean water. The company has done so with no retail presence, no celebrity endorsements, and a marketing budget that would be a rounding error for competitors like Gatorade or LMNT.
"We didn't try to out-spend the big players," says [Founder Name], who runs the company with a small team from [Location]. "We focused on the science and let our customers do the talking."

The company's secret weapon: a fanatically loyal customer base with a 45% subscription rate—nearly unheard of in the supplements industry. Customer reviews consistently mention feeling "actually different" compared to other electrolyte products, which typically contain only 3-4 minerals.
"Your body is 70% water with the same mineral composition as ocean water," the company's website explains. "Why would you replenish it with something synthetic?"

The approach has resonated particularly with the keto and carnivore diet communities, where electrolyte supplementation is considered essential. Influencers in these spaces have organically promoted the product, driving word-of-mouth growth that now accounts for 30% of new customers.

Industry analysts note that IonWave represents a broader trend of premium, science-backed supplements challenging legacy brands. "The new generation of consumers wants to understand what they're putting in their bodies," says [Analyst Name] of [Research Firm]. "They'll pay more for quality and transparency."

The company plans to expand into new product lines while maintaining its direct-to-consumer model. "We're not trying to be in every store," [Founder Name] says. "We're trying to be in every home that cares about what they consume."
For now, that strategy seems to be working.
WHAT MUST BE TRUE FOR THIS TO HAPPEN
☐ $100K MRR achieved
☐ 45%+ subscription rate
☐ 30%+ organic/referral traffic
☐ Strong review profile (4.5+ stars, 500+ reviews)
☐ Influencer community organically promoting
☐ Unit economics proven and sustainable
☐ Story is compelling and differentiated
☐ Customer testimonials are powerful and authentic
